matador.info: Adds modules for RedRaider Software Stack for Intel Cascadelake / Nvidia V100 Applications to MODULEPATH.

cmake.info: A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

gcc.info: The GNU Compiler Collection includes front ends for C, C++, Objective-C, Fortran, Ada, and Go, as well as libraries for these languages.

nvhpc.info: The NVIDIA HPC SDK is a comprehensive suite of compilers, libraries and tools essential to maximizing developer productivity and the performance and portability of HPC applications. The NVIDIA HPC SDK C, C++, and Fortran compilers support GPU acceleration of HPC modeling and simulation applications with standard C++ and Fortran, OpenACC directives, and CUDA. GPU-accelerated math libraries maximize performance on common HPC algorithms, and optimized communications libraries enable standards-based multi-GPU and scalable systems programming. Performance profiling and debugging tools simplify porting and optimization of HPC applications.

cmake.info: A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

cuda.info: CUDA is a parallel computing platform and programming model invented by NVIDIA. It enables dramatic increases in computing performance by harnessing the power of the graphics processing unit (GPU). Note: This package does not currently install the drivers necessary to run CUDA. These will need to be installed manually. See: https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/ for details.

cudnn.info: NVIDIA cuDNN is a GPU-accelerated library of primitives for deep neural networks

nccl.info: Optimized primitives for collective multi-GPU communication.

openjdk.info: The free and opensource java implementation

openmpi.info: An open source Message Passing Interface implementation. The Open MPI Project is an open source Message Passing Interface implementation that is developed and maintained by a consortium of academic, research, and industry partners. Open MPI is therefore able to combine the expertise, technologies, and resources from all across the High Performance Computing community in order to build the best MPI library available. Open MPI offers advantages for system and software vendors, application developers and computer science researchers.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

kokkos.info: Kokkos implements a programming model in C++ for writing performance portable applications targeting all major HPC platforms.

kokkos-nvcc-wrapper.info: The NVCC wrapper provides a wrapper around NVCC to make it a 'full' C++ compiler that accepts all flags

lammps.info: LAMMPS stands for Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator. This package uses patch releases, not stable release. See https://github.com/spack/spack/pull/5342 for a detailed discussion.

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

netlib-scalapack.info: ScaLAPACK is a library of high-performance linear algebra routines for parallel distributed memory machines

osu-micro-benchmarks.info: The Ohio MicroBenchmark suite is a collection of independent MPI message passing performance microbenchmarks developed and written at The Ohio State University. It includes traditional benchmarks and performance measures such as latency, bandwidth and host overhead and can be used for both traditional and GPU-enhanced nodes.

parallel-netcdf.info: PnetCDF (Parallel netCDF) is a high-performance parallel I/O library for accessing files in format compatibility with Unidata's NetCDF, specifically the formats of CDF-1, 2, and 5.

py-absl-py.info: This repository is a collection of Python library code for building Python applications. The code is collected from Google's own Python code base, and has been extensively tested and used in production.

py-astunparse.info: An AST unparser for Python. This is a factored out version of unparse found in the Python source distribution; under Demo/parser in Python 2 and under Tools/parser in Python 3.

py-cython.info: The Cython compiler for writing C extensions for the Python language.

py-gast.info: Python AST that abstracts the underlying Python version

py-google-pasta.info: pasta is an AST-based Python refactoring library.

py-keras-preprocessing.info: Utilities for working with image data, text data, and sequence data.

py-numpy.info: NumPy is the fundamental package for scientific computing with Python. It contains among other things: a powerful N-dimensional array object, sophisticated (broadcasting) functions, tools for integrating C/C++ and Fortran code, and useful linear algebra, Fourier transform, and random number capabilities

py-opt-einsum.info: Optimized Einsum: A tensor contraction order optimizer.

py-protobuf.info: Protocol buffers are Google's language-neutral, platform-neutral, extensible mechanism for serializing structured data - think XML, but smaller, faster, and simpler. You define how you want your data to be structured once, then you can use special generated source code to easily write and read your structured data to and from a variety of data streams and using a variety of languages.

py-scipy.info: SciPy (pronounced "Sigh Pie") is a Scientific Library for Python. It provides many user-friendly and efficient numerical routines such as routines for numerical integration and optimization.

py-setuptools.info: A Python utility that aids in the process of downloading, building, upgrading, installing, and uninstalling Python packages.

py-termcolor.info: ANSII Color formatting for output in terminal.

py-wrapt.info: Module for decorators, wrappers and monkey patching.

swig.info: SWIG is an interface compiler that connects programs written in C and C++ with scripting languages such as Perl, Python, Ruby, and Tcl. It works by taking the declarations found in C/C++ header files and using them to generate the wrapper code that scripting languages need to access the underlying C/C++ code. In addition, SWIG provides a variety of customization features that let you tailor the wrapping process to suit your application.

cmake.info: A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

cuda.info: CUDA is a parallel computing platform and programming model invented by NVIDIA. It enables dramatic increases in computing performance by harnessing the power of the graphics processing unit (GPU). Note: This package does not currently install the drivers necessary to run CUDA. These will need to be installed manually. See: https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/ for details.

cudnn.info: NVIDIA cuDNN is a GPU-accelerated library of primitives for deep neural networks

netlib-lapack.info: LAPACK version 3.X is a comprehensive FORTRAN library that does linear algebra operations including matrix inversions, least squared solutions to linear sets of equations, eigenvector analysis, singular value decomposition, etc. It is a very comprehensive and reputable package that has found extensive use in the scientific community.

nvhpc.info: The NVIDIA HPC SDK is a comprehensive suite of compilers, libraries and tools essential to maximizing developer productivity and the performance and portability of HPC applications. The NVIDIA HPC SDK C, C++, and Fortran compilers support GPU acceleration of HPC modeling and simulation applications with standard C++ and Fortran, OpenACC directives, and CUDA. GPU-accelerated math libraries maximize performance on common HPC algorithms, and optimized communications libraries enable standards-based multi-GPU and scalable systems programming. Performance profiling and debugging tools simplify porting and optimization of HPC applications.

openmpi.info: An open source Message Passing Interface implementation. The Open MPI Project is an open source Message Passing Interface implementation that is developed and maintained by a consortium of academic, research, and industry partners. Open MPI is therefore able to combine the expertise, technologies, and resources from all across the High Performance Computing community in order to build the best MPI library available. Open MPI offers advantages for system and software vendors, application developers and computer science researchers.

boost.info: Boost provides free peer-reviewed portable C++ source libraries, emphasizing libraries that work well with the C++ Standard Library. Boost libraries are intended to be widely useful, and usable across a broad spectrum of applications. The Boost license encourages both commercial and non-commercial use.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

hpx.info: C++ runtime system for parallel and distributed applications.

netcdf-fortran.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the Fortran distribution.

We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

hpl.info: HPL is a software package that solves a (random) dense linear system in double precision (64 bits) arithmetic on distributed-memory computers. It can thus be regarded as a portable as well as freely available implementation of the High Performance Computing Linpack Benchmark.

It includes traditional benchmarks and performance measures such as latency, bandwidth and host overhead and can be used for both traditional and GPU-enhanced nodes.

vasp.info: The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) is a computer program for atomic scale materials modelling, e.g. electronic structure calculations and quantum-mechanical molecular dynamics, from first principles.

It works by taking the declarations found in C/C++ header files and using them to generate the wrapper code that scripting languages need to access the underlying C/C++ code. In addition, SWIG provides a variety of customization features that let you tailor the wrapping process to suit your application.

git.info: Git is a free and open source distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency.

matlab.info: MATLAB (MATrix LABoratory) is a multi-paradigm numerical computing environment and fourth-generation programming language. A proprietary programming language developed by MathWorks, MATLAB allows matrix manipulations, plotting of functions and data, implementation of algorithms, creation of user interfaces, and interfacing with programs written in other languages, including C, C++, C#, Java, Fortran and Python. Note: MATLAB is licensed software. You will need to create an account on the MathWorks homepage and download MATLAB yourself. Spack will search your current directory for the download file. Alternatively, add this file to a mirror so that Spack can find it. For instructions on how to set up a mirror, see http://spack.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mirrors.html

nocona.info: Adds modules for RedRaider Software Stack for AMD ROME Applications to MODULEPATH.

cmake.info: A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

gcc.info: The GNU Compiler Collection includes front ends for C, C++, Objective-C, Fortran, Ada, and Go, as well as libraries for these languages.

bcftools.info: BCFtools is a set of utilities that manipulate variant calls in the Variant Call Format (VCF) and its binary counterpart BCF. All commands work transparently with both VCFs and BCFs, both uncompressed and BGZF- compressed.

bedtools2.info: Collectively, the bedtools utilities are a swiss-army knife of tools for a wide-range of genomics analysis tasks. The most widely-used tools enable genome arithmetic: that is, set theory on the genome.

boost.info: Boost provides free peer-reviewed portable C++ source libraries, emphasizing libraries that work well with the C++ Standard Library. Boost libraries are intended to be widely useful, and usable across a broad spectrum of applications. The Boost license encourages both commercial and non-commercial use.

charmpp.info: Charm++ is a parallel programming framework in C++ supported by an adaptive runtime system, which enhances user productivity and allows programs to run portably from small multicore computers (your laptop) to the largest supercomputers.

cmake.info: A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

emboss.info: EMBOSS is a free Open Source software analysis package specially developed for the needs of the molecular biology (e.g. EMBnet) user community

fastx-toolkit.info: The FASTX-Toolkit is a collection of command line tools for Short-Reads FASTA/FASTQ files preprocessing.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

gdal.info: GDAL (Geospatial Data Abstraction Library) is a translator library for raster and vector geospatial data formats that is released under an X/MIT style Open Source license by the Open Source Geospatial Foundation. As a library, it presents a single raster abstract data model and vector abstract data model to the calling application for all supported formats. It also comes with a variety of useful command line utilities for data translation and processing.

geant4.info: Geant4 is a toolkit for the simulation of the passage of particles through matter. Its areas of application include high energy, nuclear and accelerator physics, as well as studies in medical and space science.

gnuplot.info: Gnuplot is a portable command-line driven graphing utility for Linux, OS/2, MS Windows, OSX, VMS, and many other platforms. The source code is copyrighted but freely distributed (i.e., you don't have to pay for it). It was originally created to allow scientists and students to visualize mathematical functions and data interactively, but has grown to support many non-interactive uses such as web scripting. It is also used as a plotting engine by third-party applications like Octave. Gnuplot has been supported and under active development since 1986

gsl.info: The GNU Scientific Library (GSL) is a numerical library for C and C++ programmers. It is free software under the GNU General Public License. The library provides a wide range of mathematical routines such as random number generators, special functions and least-squares fitting. There are over 1000 functions in total with an extensive test suite.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

htslib.info: C library for high-throughput sequencing data formats.

libxc.info: Libxc is a library of exchange-correlation functionals for density- functional theory.

mafft.info: MAFFT is a multiple sequence alignment program for unix-like operating systems. It offers a range of multiple alignment methods, L-INS-i (accurate; for alignment of <~200 sequences), FFT-NS-2 (fast; for alignment of <~30,000 sequences), etc.

nco.info: The NCO toolkit manipulates and analyzes data stored in netCDF- accessible formats

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

netcdf-fortran.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the Fortran distribution.

netlib-lapack.info: LAPACK version 3.X is a comprehensive FORTRAN library that does linear algebra operations including matrix inversions, least squared solutions to linear sets of equations, eigenvector analysis, singular value decomposition, etc. It is a very comprehensive and reputable package that has found extensive use in the scientific community.

octave.info: GNU Octave is a high-level language, primarily intended for numerical computations. It provides a convenient command line interface for solving linear and nonlinear problems numerically, and for performing other numerical experiments using a language that is mostly compatible with Matlab. It may also be used as a batch-oriented language.

openjdk.info: The free and opensource java implementation

openmpi.info: An open source Message Passing Interface implementation. The Open MPI Project is an open source Message Passing Interface implementation that is developed and maintained by a consortium of academic, research, and industry partners. Open MPI is therefore able to combine the expertise, technologies, and resources from all across the High Performance Computing community in order to build the best MPI library available. Open MPI offers advantages for system and software vendors, application developers and computer science researchers.

boost.info: Boost provides free peer-reviewed portable C++ source libraries, emphasizing libraries that work well with the C++ Standard Library. Boost libraries are intended to be widely useful, and usable across a broad spectrum of applications. The Boost license encourages both commercial and non-commercial use.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

gromacs.info: GROMACS (GROningen MAchine for Chemical Simulations) is a molecular dynamics package primarily designed for simulations of proteins, lipids and nucleic acids. It was originally developed in the Biophysical Chemistry department of University of Groningen, and is now maintained by contributors in universities and research centers across the world. GROMACS is one of the fastest and most popular software packages available and can run on CPUs as well as GPUs. It is free, open source released under the GNU General Public License. Starting from version 4.6, GROMACS is released under the GNU Lesser General Public License.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

hpl.info: HPL is a software package that solves a (random) dense linear system in double precision (64 bits) arithmetic on distributed-memory computers. It can thus be regarded as a portable as well as freely available implementation of the High Performance Computing Linpack Benchmark.

lammps.info: LAMMPS stands for Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator. This package uses patch releases, not stable release. See https://github.com/spack/spack/pull/5342 for a detailed discussion.

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

netcdf-cxx4.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C++ distribution.

netcdf-fortran.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the Fortran distribution.

netlib-scalapack.info: ScaLAPACK is a library of high-performance linear algebra routines for parallel distributed memory machines

orca.info: An ab initio, DFT and semiempirical SCF-MO package Note: Orca is licensed software. You will need to create an account on the Orca homepage and download Orca yourself. Spack will search your current directory for the download file. Alternatively, add this file to a mirror so that Spack can find it. For instructions on how to set up a mirror, see http://spack.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mirrors.html

parallel-netcdf.info: PnetCDF (Parallel netCDF) is a high-performance parallel I/O library for accessing files in format compatibility with Unidata's NetCDF, specifically the formats of CDF-1, 2, and 5.

vasp.info: The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) is a computer program for atomic scale materials modelling, e.g. electronic structure calculations and quantum-mechanical molecular dynamics, from first principles.

namd.info: NAMDis a parallel molecular dynamics code designed for high-performance simulation of large biomolecular systems.

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

netcdf-fortran.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the Fortran distribution.

netlib-scalapack.info: ScaLAPACK is a library of high-performance linear algebra routines for parallel distributed memory machines

openfoam.info: OpenFOAM is a GPL-opensource C++ CFD-toolbox. This offering is supported by OpenCFD Ltd, producer and distributor of the OpenFOAM software via www.openfoam.com, and owner of the OPENFOAM trademark. OpenCFD Ltd has been developing and releasing OpenFOAM since its debut in 2004.

osu-micro-benchmarks.info: The Ohio MicroBenchmark suite is a collection of independent MPI message passing performance microbenchmarks developed and written at The Ohio State University. It includes traditional benchmarks and performance measures such as latency, bandwidth and host overhead and can be used for both traditional and GPU-enhanced nodes.

paraview.info: ParaView is an open-source, multi-platform data analysis and visualization application.

vasp.info: The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) is a computer program for atomic scale materials modelling, e.g. electronic structure calculations and quantum-mechanical molecular dynamics, from first principles.

perl.info: Perl 5 is a highly capable, feature-rich programming language with over 27 years of development.

py-matplotlib.info: Matplotlib is a comprehensive library for creating static, animated, and interactive visualizations in Python.

py-numpy.info: NumPy is the fundamental package for scientific computing with Python. It contains among other things: a powerful N-dimensional array object, sophisticated (broadcasting) functions, tools for integrating C/C++ and Fortran code, and useful linear algebra, Fourier transform, and random number capabilities

r.info: R is 'GNU S', a freely available language and environment for statistical computing and graphics which provides a wide variety of statistical and graphical techniques: linear and nonlinear modelling, statistical tests, time series analysis, classification, clustering, etc. Please consult the R project homepage for further information.

root.info: ROOT is a data analysis framework.

samtools.info: SAM Tools provide various utilities for manipulating alignments in the SAM format, including sorting, merging, indexing and generating alignments in a per-position format

stacks.info: Stacks is a software pipeline for building loci from short-read sequences, such as those generated on the Illumina platform.

vasp.info: The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) is a computer program for atomic scale materials modelling, e.g. electronic structure calculations and quantum-mechanical molecular dynamics, from first principles.

zlib.info: A free, general-purpose, legally unencumbered lossless data-compression library.

zstd.info: Zstandard, or zstd as short version, is a fast lossless compression algorithm, targeting real-time compression scenarios at zlib-level and better compression ratios.

boost.info: Boost provides free peer-reviewed portable C++ source libraries, emphasizing libraries that work well with the C++ Standard Library. Boost libraries are intended to be widely useful, and usable across a broad spectrum of applications. The Boost license encourages both commercial and non-commercial use.

netlib-scalapack.info: ScaLAPACK is a library of high-performance linear algebra routines for parallel distributed memory machines

openfoam.info: OpenFOAM is a GPL-opensource C++ CFD-toolbox. This offering is supported by OpenCFD Ltd, producer and distributor of the OpenFOAM software via www.openfoam.com, and owner of the OPENFOAM trademark. OpenCFD Ltd has been developing and releasing OpenFOAM since its debut in 2004.

paraview.info: ParaView is an open-source, multi-platform data analysis and visualization application.

vasp.info: The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) is a computer program for atomic scale materials modelling, e.g. electronic structure calculations and quantum-mechanical molecular dynamics, from first principles.

vasp-vtst.info: The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) is a computer program for atomic scale materials modelling, e.g. electronic structure calculations and quantum-mechanical molecular dynamics, from first principles.

perl.info: Perl 5 is a highly capable, feature-rich programming language with over 27 years of development.

zlib.info: A free, general-purpose, legally unencumbered lossless data-compression library.

zstd.info: Zstandard, or zstd as short version, is a fast lossless compression algorithm, targeting real-time compression scenarios at zlib-level and better compression ratios.

abyss.info: ABySS is a de novo, parallel, paired-end sequence assembler that is designed for short reads. The single-processor version is useful for assembling genomes up to 100 Mbases in size.

bcftools.info: BCFtools is a set of utilities that manipulate variant calls in the Variant Call Format (VCF) and its binary counterpart BCF. All commands work transparently with both VCFs and BCFs, both uncompressed and BGZF- compressed.

boost.info: Boost provides free peer-reviewed portable C++ source libraries, emphasizing libraries that work well with the C++ Standard Library. Boost libraries are intended to be widely useful, and usable across a broad spectrum of applications. The Boost license encourages both commercial and non-commercial use.

bowtie2.info: Bowtie 2 is an ultrafast and memory-efficient tool for aligning sequencing reads to long reference sequences

bwa.info: Burrow-Wheeler Aligner for pairwise alignment between DNA sequences.

cmake.info: A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

dos2unix.info: DOS/Mac to Unix and vice versa text file format converter.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

gnuplot.info: Gnuplot is a portable command-line driven graphing utility for Linux, OS/2, MS Windows, OSX, VMS, and many other platforms. The source code is copyrighted but freely distributed (i.e., you don't have to pay for it). It was originally created to allow scientists and students to visualize mathematical functions and data interactively, but has grown to support many non-interactive uses such as web scripting. It is also used as a plotting engine by third-party applications like Octave. Gnuplot has been supported and under active development since 1986

gsl.info: The GNU Scientific Library (GSL) is a numerical library for C and C++ programmers. It is free software under the GNU General Public License. The library provides a wide range of mathematical routines such as random number generators, special functions and least-squares fitting. There are over 1000 functions in total with an extensive test suite.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

htslib.info: C library for high-throughput sequencing data formats.

maker.info: MAKER is a portable and easily configurable genome annotation pipeline. It's purpose is to allow smaller eukaryotic and prokaryotic genomeprojects to independently annotate their genomes and to create genome databases. MAKER identifies repeats, aligns ESTs and proteins to a genome, produces ab-initio gene predictions and automatically synthesizes these data into gene annotations having evidence-based quality values. MAKER is also easily trainable: outputs of preliminary runs can be used to automatically retrain its gene prediction algorithm, producing higher quality gene-models on subsequent runs. MAKER's inputs are minimal and its ouputs can be directly loaded into a GMOD database. They can also be viewed in the Apollo genome browser; this feature of MAKER provides an easy means to annotate, view and edit individual contigs and BACs without the overhead of a database. MAKER should prove especially useful for emerging model organism projects with minimal bioinformatics expertise and computer resources. Note: MAKER requires registration. Fill out the form at http://yandell.topaz.genetics.utah.edu/cgi-bin/maker_license.cgi to get a download link. Spack will search your current directory for the download file. Alternatively, add this file to a mirror so that Spack can find it. For instructions on how to set up a mirror, see http://spack.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mirrors.html

molden.info: A package for displaying Molecular Density from various Ab Initio packages

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

openjdk.info: The free and opensource java implementation

openmpi.info: An open source Message Passing Interface implementation. The Open MPI Project is an open source Message Passing Interface implementation that is developed and maintained by a consortium of academic, research, and industry partners. Open MPI is therefore able to combine the expertise, technologies, and resources from all across the High Performance Computing community in order to build the best MPI library available. Open MPI offers advantages for system and software vendors, application developers and computer science researchers.

paraview.info: ParaView is an open-source, multi-platform data analysis and visualization application.

perl.info: Perl 5 is a highly capable, feature-rich programming language with over 27 years of development.

py-matplotlib.info: Matplotlib is a comprehensive library for creating static, animated, and interactive visualizations in Python.

py-numpy.info: NumPy is the fundamental package for scientific computing with Python. It contains among other things: a powerful N-dimensional array object, sophisticated (broadcasting) functions, tools for integrating C/C++ and Fortran code, and useful linear algebra, Fourier transform, and random number capabilities

repeatmasker.info: RepeatMasker is a program that screens DNA sequences for interspersed repeats and low complexity DNA sequences.

rosetta.info: Rosetta is a very large software suite for macromolecular modeling.

samtools.info: SAM Tools provide various utilities for manipulating alignments in the SAM format, including sorting, merging, indexing and generating alignments in a per-position format

zlib.info: A free, general-purpose, legally unencumbered lossless data-compression library.

zstd.info: Zstandard, or zstd as short version, is a fast lossless compression algorithm, targeting real-time compression scenarios at zlib-level and better compression ratios.

git.info: Git is a free and open source distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency.

perl.info: Perl 5 is a highly capable, feature-rich programming language with over 27 years of development.

intel-tbb.info: Widely used C++ template library for task parallelism. Intel Threading Building Blocks (Intel TBB) lets you easily write parallel C++ programs that take full advantage of multicore performance, that are portable and composable, and that have future-proof scalability.

matlab.info: MATLAB (MATrix LABoratory) is a multi-paradigm numerical computing environment and fourth-generation programming language. A proprietary programming language developed by MathWorks, MATLAB allows matrix manipulations, plotting of functions and data, implementation of algorithms, creation of user interfaces, and interfacing with programs written in other languages, including C, C++, C#, Java, Fortran and Python. Note: MATLAB is licensed software. You will need to create an account on the MathWorks homepage and download MATLAB yourself. Spack will search your current directory for the download file. Alternatively, add this file to a mirror so that Spack can find it. For instructions on how to set up a mirror, see http://spack.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mirrors.html

openfoam.info: OpenFOAM is a GPL-opensource C++ CFD-toolbox. This offering is supported by OpenCFD Ltd, producer and distributor of the OpenFOAM software via www.openfoam.com, and owner of the OPENFOAM trademark. OpenCFD Ltd has been developing and releasing OpenFOAM since its debut in 2004.

perl.info: Perl 5 is a highly capable, feature-rich programming language with over 27 years of development.

quanah.info: Adds modules for RedRaider Software Stack for Intel Broadwell Applications to MODULEPATH.

bismark.info: A tool to map bisulfite converted sequence reads and determine cytosine methylation states

cmake.info: A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

cufflinks.info: Cufflinks assembles transcripts, estimates their abundances, and tests for differential expression and regulation in RNA-Seq samples.

fsl.info: FSL is a comprehensive library of analysis tools for FMRI, MRI and DTI brain imaging data.

gcc.info: The GNU Compiler Collection includes front ends for C, C++, Objective-C, Fortran, Ada, and Go, as well as libraries for these languages.

bamtools.info: C++ API & command-line toolkit for working with BAM data.

bcftools.info: BCFtools is a set of utilities that manipulate variant calls in the Variant Call Format (VCF) and its binary counterpart BCF. All commands work transparently with both VCFs and BCFs, both uncompressed and BGZF- compressed.

bedtools2.info: Collectively, the bedtools utilities are a swiss-army knife of tools for a wide-range of genomics analysis tasks. The most widely-used tools enable genome arithmetic: that is, set theory on the genome.

bowtie2.info: Bowtie 2 is an ultrafast and memory-efficient tool for aligning sequencing reads to long reference sequences

clustalw.info: Multiple alignment of nucleic acid and protein sequences.

cmake.info: A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

cufflinks.info: Cufflinks assembles transcripts, estimates their abundances, and tests for differential expression and regulation in RNA-Seq samples.

eigen.info: Eigen is a C++ template library for linear algebra matrices, vectors, numerical solvers, and related algorithms.

exonerate.info: Pairwise sequence alignment of DNA and proteins

fastx-toolkit.info: The FASTX-Toolkit is a collection of command line tools for Short-Reads FASTA/FASTQ files preprocessing.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

gatk.info: Genome Analysis Toolkit Variant Discovery in High-Throughput Sequencing Data

gdal.info: GDAL (Geospatial Data Abstraction Library) is a translator library for raster and vector geospatial data formats that is released under an X/MIT style Open Source license by the Open Source Geospatial Foundation. As a library, it presents a single raster abstract data model and vector abstract data model to the calling application for all supported formats. It also comes with a variety of useful command line utilities for data translation and processing.

geos.info: GEOS (Geometry Engine - Open Source) is a C++ port of the Java Topology Suite (JTS). As such, it aims to contain the complete functionality of JTS in C++. This includes all the OpenGIS Simple Features for SQL spatial predicate functions and spatial operators, as well as specific JTS enhanced topology functions.

git.info: Git is a free and open source distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency.

gnuplot.info: Gnuplot is a portable command-line driven graphing utility for Linux, OS/2, MS Windows, OSX, VMS, and many other platforms. The source code is copyrighted but freely distributed (i.e., you don't have to pay for it). It was originally created to allow scientists and students to visualize mathematical functions and data interactively, but has grown to support many non-interactive uses such as web scripting. It is also used as a plotting engine by third-party applications like Octave. Gnuplot has been supported and under active development since 1986

grads.info: The Grid Analysis and Display System (GrADS) is an interactive desktop tool that is used for easy access, manipulation, and visualization of earth science data. GrADS has two data models for handling gridded and station data. GrADS supports many data file formats, including binary (stream or sequential), GRIB (version 1 and 2), NetCDF, HDF (version 4 and 5), and BUFR (for station data).

gsl.info: The GNU Scientific Library (GSL) is a numerical library for C and C++ programmers. It is free software under the GNU General Public License. The library provides a wide range of mathematical routines such as random number generators, special functions and least-squares fitting. There are over 1000 functions in total with an extensive test suite.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

netlib-scalapack.info: ScaLAPACK is a library of high-performance linear algebra routines for parallel distributed memory machines

intel-tbb.info: Widely used C++ template library for task parallelism. Intel Threading Building Blocks (Intel TBB) lets you easily write parallel C++ programs that take full advantage of multicore performance, that are portable and composable, and that have future-proof scalability.

libxc.info: Libxc is a library of exchange-correlation functionals for density- functional theory.

lmod.info: Lmod is a Lua based module system that easily handles the MODULEPATH Hierarchical problem. Environment Modules provide a convenient way to dynamically change the users' environment through modulefiles. This includes easily adding or removing directories to the PATH environment variable. Modulefiles for Library packages provide environment variables that specify where the library and header files can be found.

mafft.info: MAFFT is a multiple sequence alignment program for unix-like operating systems. It offers a range of multiple alignment methods, L-INS-i (accurate; for alignment of <~200 sequences), FFT-NS-2 (fast; for alignment of <~30,000 sequences), etc.

nco.info: The NCO toolkit manipulates and analyzes data stored in netCDF- accessible formats

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

netcdf-fortran.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the Fortran distribution.

netlib-lapack.info: LAPACK version 3.X is a comprehensive FORTRAN library that does linear algebra operations including matrix inversions, least squared solutions to linear sets of equations, eigenvector analysis, singular value decomposition, etc. It is a very comprehensive and reputable package that has found extensive use in the scientific community.

openmpi.info: An open source Message Passing Interface implementation. The Open MPI Project is an open source Message Passing Interface implementation that is developed and maintained by a consortium of academic, research, and industry partners. Open MPI is therefore able to combine the expertise, technologies, and resources from all across the High Performance Computing community in order to build the best MPI library available. Open MPI offers advantages for system and software vendors, application developers and computer science researchers.

boost.info: Boost provides free peer-reviewed portable C++ source libraries, emphasizing libraries that work well with the C++ Standard Library. Boost libraries are intended to be widely useful, and usable across a broad spectrum of applications. The Boost license encourages both commercial and non-commercial use.

cgal.info: The Computational Geometry Algorithms Library (CGAL) is a C++ library that aims to provide easy access to efficient and reliable algorithms in computational geometry. CGAL is used in various areas needing geometric computation, such as geographic information systems, computer aided design, molecular biology, medical imaging, computer graphics, and robotics.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

gromacs.info: GROMACS (GROningen MAchine for Chemical Simulations) is a molecular dynamics package primarily designed for simulations of proteins, lipids and nucleic acids. It was originally developed in the Biophysical Chemistry department of University of Groningen, and is now maintained by contributors in universities and research centers across the world. GROMACS is one of the fastest and most popular software packages available and can run on CPUs as well as GPUs. It is free, open source released under the GNU General Public License. Starting from version 4.6, GROMACS is released under the GNU Lesser General Public License.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

hmmer.info: HMMER is used for searching sequence databases for sequence homologs, and for making sequence alignments. It implements methods using probabilistic models called profile hidden Markov models (profile HMMs).

hpl.info: HPL is a software package that solves a (random) dense linear system in double precision (64 bits) arithmetic on distributed-memory computers. It can thus be regarded as a portable as well as freely available implementation of the High Performance Computing Linpack Benchmark.

libint.info: Libint is a high-performance library for computing Gaussian integrals in quantum mechanics.

namd.info: NAMDis a parallel molecular dynamics code designed for high-performance simulation of large biomolecular systems.

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

netcdf-cxx4.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C++ distribution.

netcdf-fortran.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the Fortran distribution.

netlib-scalapack.info: ScaLAPACK is a library of high-performance linear algebra routines for parallel distributed memory machines

osu-micro-benchmarks.info: The Ohio MicroBenchmark suite is a collection of independent MPI message passing performance microbenchmarks developed and written at The Ohio State University. It includes traditional benchmarks and performance measures such as latency, bandwidth and host overhead and can be used for both traditional and GPU-enhanced nodes.

parallel-netcdf.info: PnetCDF (Parallel netCDF) is a high-performance parallel I/O library for accessing files in format compatibility with Unidata's NetCDF, specifically the formats of CDF-1, 2, and 5.

plumed.info: PLUMED is an open source library for free energy calculations in molecular systems which works together with some of the most popular molecular dynamics engines. Free energy calculations can be performed as a function of many order parameters with a particular focus on biological problems, using state of the art methods such as metadynamics, umbrella sampling and Jarzynski-equation based steered MD. The software, written in C++, can be easily interfaced with both fortran and C/C++ codes.

vasp.info: The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) is a computer program for atomic scale materials modelling, e.g. electronic structure calculations and quantum-mechanical molecular dynamics, from first principles.

perl.info: Perl 5 is a highly capable, feature-rich programming language with over 27 years of development.

picard.info: Picard is a set of command line tools for manipulating high-throughput sequencing (HTS) data and formats such as SAM/BAM/CRAM and VCF.

proj.info: PROJ is a generic coordinate transformation software, that transforms geospatial coordinates from one coordinate reference system (CRS) to another. This includes cartographic projections as well as geodetic transformations.

py-numpy.info: NumPy is the fundamental package for scientific computing with Python. It contains among other things: a powerful N-dimensional array object, sophisticated (broadcasting) functions, tools for integrating C/C++ and Fortran code, and useful linear algebra, Fourier transform, and random number capabilities

r.info: R is 'GNU S', a freely available language and environment for statistical computing and graphics which provides a wide variety of statistical and graphical techniques: linear and nonlinear modelling, statistical tests, time series analysis, classification, clustering, etc. Please consult the R project homepage for further information.

root.info: ROOT is a data analysis framework.

samtools.info: SAM Tools provide various utilities for manipulating alignments in the SAM format, including sorting, merging, indexing and generating alignments in a per-position format

singularity.info: Singularity is a container technology focused on building portable encapsulated environments to support "Mobility of Compute" For older versions of Singularity (pre 3.0) you should use singularity-legacy, which has a different install base (Autotools). Needs post-install chmod/chown steps to enable full functionality. See package definition or `spack-build-out.txt` build log for details, e.g. tail -15 $(spack location -i singularity)/.spack/spack-build-out.txt

sparsehash.info: Sparse and dense hash-tables for C++ by Google

stacks.info: Stacks is a software pipeline for building loci from short-read sequences, such as those generated on the Illumina platform.

tcl.info: Tcl (Tool Command Language) is a very powerful but easy to learn dynamic programming language, suitable for a very wide range of uses, including web and desktop applications, networking, administration, testing and many more. Open source and business-friendly, Tcl is a mature yet evolving language that is truly cross platform, easily deployed and highly extensible.

tmux.info: Tmux is a terminal multiplexer. What is a terminal multiplexer? It lets you switch easily between several programs in one terminal, detach them (they keep running in the background) and reattach them to a different terminal. And do a lot more.

trf.info: Tandem Repeats Finder is a program to locate and display tandem repeats in DNA sequences. Note: A manual download is required for TRF. Spack will search your current directory for the download file. Alternatively, add this file to a mirror so that Spack can find it. For instructions on how to set up a mirror, see http://spack.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mirrors.html

vcftools.info: VCFtools is a program package designed for working with VCF files, such as those generated by the 1000 Genomes Project. The aim of VCFtools is to provide easily accessible methods for working with complex genetic variation data in the form of VCF files.

voropp.info: Voro++ is a open source software library for the computation of the Voronoi diagram, a widely-used tessellation that has applications in many scientific fields.

vsearch.info: VSEARCH is a versatile open-source tool for metagenomics.

cmake.info: A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

molden.info: A package for displaying Molecular Density from various Ab Initio packages

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

openmpi.info: An open source Message Passing Interface implementation. The Open MPI Project is an open source Message Passing Interface implementation that is developed and maintained by a consortium of academic, research, and industry partners. Open MPI is therefore able to combine the expertise, technologies, and resources from all across the High Performance Computing community in order to build the best MPI library available. Open MPI offers advantages for system and software vendors, application developers and computer science researchers.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

hpl.info: HPL is a software package that solves a (random) dense linear system in double precision (64 bits) arithmetic on distributed-memory computers. It can thus be regarded as a portable as well as freely available implementation of the High Performance Computing Linpack Benchmark.

lammps.info: LAMMPS stands for Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator. This package uses patch releases, not stable release. See https://github.com/spack/spack/pull/5342 for a detailed discussion.

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

netlib-scalapack.info: ScaLAPACK is a library of high-performance linear algebra routines for parallel distributed memory machines

py-h5py.info: The h5py package provides both a high- and low-level interface to the HDF5 library from Python.

py-mpi4py.info: This package provides Python bindings for the Message Passing Interface (MPI) standard. It is implemented on top of the MPI-1/MPI-2 specification and exposes an API which grounds on the standard MPI-2 C++ bindings.

repeatmasker.info: RepeatMasker is a program that screens DNA sequences for interspersed repeats and low complexity DNA sequences.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

perl.info: Perl 5 is a highly capable, feature-rich programming language with over 27 years of development.

py-numpy.info: NumPy is the fundamental package for scientific computing with Python. It contains among other things: a powerful N-dimensional array object, sophisticated (broadcasting) functions, tools for integrating C/C++ and Fortran code, and useful linear algebra, Fourier transform, and random number capabilities

voropp.info: Voro++ is a open source software library for the computation of the Voronoi diagram, a widely-used tessellation that has applications in many scientific fields.

hisat2.info: HISAT2 is a fast and sensitive alignment program for mapping next- generation sequencing reads (whole-genome, transcriptome, and exome sequencing data) against the general human population (as well as against a single reference genome).

ncl.info: NCL is an interpreted language designed specifically for scientific data analysis and visualization. Supports NetCDF 3/4, GRIB 1/2, HDF 4/5, HDF- EOD 2/5, shapefile, ASCII, binary. Numerous analysis functions are built-in.

openfoam.info: OpenFOAM is a GPL-opensource C++ CFD-toolbox. This offering is supported by OpenCFD Ltd, producer and distributor of the OpenFOAM software via www.openfoam.com, and owner of the OPENFOAM trademark. OpenCFD Ltd has been developing and releasing OpenFOAM since its debut in 2004.

paml.info: PAML is a package of programs for phylogenetic analyses of DNA or protein sewuences using maximum likelihood.

perl.info: Perl 5 is a highly capable, feature-rich programming language with over 27 years of development.

presto.info: Presto is a distributed SQL query engine for big data.

trinity.info: Trinity, developed at the Broad Institute and the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, represents a novel method for the efficient and robust de novo reconstruction of transcriptomes from RNA-seq data. Trinity combines three independent software modules: Inchworm, Chrysalis, and Butterfly, applied sequentially to process large volumes of RNA-seq reads. Trinity partitions the sequence data into many individual de Bruijn graphs, each representing the transcriptional complexity at a given gene or locus, and then processes each graph independently to extract full-length splicing isoforms and to tease apart transcripts derived from paralogous genes.

quanah-CentOS.7.info: Quanah/CentOS-7 Lmod Software Stack for Intel Broadwell and CentOS 7 on RedRaider Cluster

cmake.info: CMake is a cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

eigen.info: A C++ template library for linear algebra: matrices, vectors, numerical solvers, and related algorithms.

fsl.info: A C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data

gnu.info: An open source software library for the computation of the Voronoi diagram

gnu7.info: An open source software library for the computation of the Voronoi diagram

grads.info: The Grid Analysis and Display System (GrADS) is an interactive desktop tool that is used for easy access, manipulation, and visualization of earth science data.

intel.info: An open source software library for the computation of the Voronoi diagram

perl.info: Perl Libararies and Modules in additiobn to the default system /bin/perl

prun.info: job launch utility for multiple MPI families

rosetta.info: The Rosetta software suite includes algorithms for computational modeling and analysis of protein structures. It has enabled notable scientific advances in computational biology, including de novo protein design, enzyme design, ligand docking, and structure prediction of biological macromolecules and macromolecular complexes.

singularity.info: Singularity provides functionality to build the smallest most minimal possible containers, and running those containers as single application environments

vasp.info: Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package. Compiled using Intel Compilers. This installation has the standard, gamma-only, and non-collinear version of VASP, based on your needs you may use the command 'vasp_std', 'vasp_gam' or 'vasp_ncl'.

toreador.info: Adds modules for RedRaider Software Stack for AMD ROAM / Nvidia A100 Applications to MODULEPATH.

cmake.info: A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

gcc.info: The GNU Compiler Collection includes front ends for C, C++, Objective-C, Fortran, Ada, and Go, as well as libraries for these languages.

cuda.info: CUDA is a parallel computing platform and programming model invented by NVIDIA. It enables dramatic increases in computing performance by harnessing the power of the graphics processing unit (GPU). Note: This package does not currently install the drivers necessary to run CUDA. These will need to be installed manually. See: https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/ for details.

cudnn.info: NVIDIA cuDNN is a GPU-accelerated library of primitives for deep neural networks

cmake.info: A cross-platform, open-source build system. CMake is a family of tools designed to build, test and package software.

cuda.info: CUDA is a parallel computing platform and programming model invented by NVIDIA. It enables dramatic increases in computing performance by harnessing the power of the graphics processing unit (GPU). Note: This package does not currently install the drivers necessary to run CUDA. These will need to be installed manually. See: https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/ for details.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

kokkos.info: Kokkos implements a programming model in C++ for writing performance portable applications targeting all major HPC platforms.

libmatheval.info: GNU libmatheval is a library (callable from C and Fortran) to parse and evaluate symbolic expressions input as text. It supports expressions in any number of variables of arbitrary names, decimal and symbolic constants, basic unary and binary operators, and elementary mathematical functions. In addition to parsing and evaluation, libmatheval can also compute symbolic derivatives and output expressions to strings.

libunwind.info: A portable and efficient C programming interface (API) to determine the call-chain of a program.

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

netcdf-fortran.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the Fortran distribution.

netlib-lapack.info: LAPACK version 3.X is a comprehensive FORTRAN library that does linear algebra operations including matrix inversions, least squared solutions to linear sets of equations, eigenvector analysis, singular value decomposition, etc. It is a very comprehensive and reputable package that has found extensive use in the scientific community.

nvhpc.info: The NVIDIA HPC SDK is a comprehensive suite of compilers, libraries and tools essential to maximizing developer productivity and the performance and portability of HPC applications. The NVIDIA HPC SDK C, C++, and Fortran compilers support GPU acceleration of HPC modeling and simulation applications with standard C++ and Fortran, OpenACC directives, and CUDA. GPU-accelerated math libraries maximize performance on common HPC algorithms, and optimized communications libraries enable standards-based multi-GPU and scalable systems programming. Performance profiling and debugging tools simplify porting and optimization of HPC applications.

openmpi.info: An open source Message Passing Interface implementation. The Open MPI Project is an open source Message Passing Interface implementation that is developed and maintained by a consortium of academic, research, and industry partners. Open MPI is therefore able to combine the expertise, technologies, and resources from all across the High Performance Computing community in order to build the best MPI library available. Open MPI offers advantages for system and software vendors, application developers and computer science researchers.

boost.info: Boost provides free peer-reviewed portable C++ source libraries, emphasizing libraries that work well with the C++ Standard Library. Boost libraries are intended to be widely useful, and usable across a broad spectrum of applications. The Boost license encourages both commercial and non-commercial use.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

hpx.info: C++ runtime system for parallel and distributed applications.

kokkos.info: Kokkos implements a programming model in C++ for writing performance portable applications targeting all major HPC platforms.

kokkos-nvcc-wrapper.info: The NVCC wrapper provides a wrapper around NVCC to make it a 'full' C++ compiler that accepts all flags

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

netcdf-cxx4.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C++ distribution.

netcdf-fortran.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the Fortran distribution.

netlib-scalapack.info: ScaLAPACK is a library of high-performance linear algebra routines for parallel distributed memory machines

parallel-netcdf.info: PnetCDF (Parallel netCDF) is a high-performance parallel I/O library for accessing files in format compatibility with Unidata's NetCDF, specifically the formats of CDF-1, 2, and 5.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

hpl.info: HPL is a software package that solves a (random) dense linear system in double precision (64 bits) arithmetic on distributed-memory computers. It can thus be regarded as a portable as well as freely available implementation of the High Performance Computing Linpack Benchmark.

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

netcdf-cxx4.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C++ distribution.

netcdf-fortran.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the Fortran distribution.

netlib-scalapack.info: ScaLAPACK is a library of high-performance linear algebra routines for parallel distributed memory machines

parallel-netcdf.info: PnetCDF (Parallel netCDF) is a high-performance parallel I/O library for accessing files in format compatibility with Unidata's NetCDF, specifically the formats of CDF-1, 2, and 5.

vasp.info: The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) is a computer program for atomic scale materials modelling, e.g. electronic structure calculations and quantum-mechanical molecular dynamics, from first principles.

fftw.info: FFTW is a C subroutine library for computing the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in one or more dimensions, of arbitrary input size, and of both real and complex data (as well as of even/odd data, i.e. the discrete cosine/sine transforms or DCT/DST). We believe that FFTW, which is free software, should become the FFT library of choice for most applications.

hdf5.info: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data. It supports an unlimited variety of datatypes, and is designed for flexible and efficient I/O and for high volume and complex data.

hpl.info: HPL is a software package that solves a (random) dense linear system in double precision (64 bits) arithmetic on distributed-memory computers. It can thus be regarded as a portable as well as freely available implementation of the High Performance Computing Linpack Benchmark.

kokkos.info: Kokkos implements a programming model in C++ for writing performance portable applications targeting all major HPC platforms.

kokkos-nvcc-wrapper.info: The NVCC wrapper provides a wrapper around NVCC to make it a 'full' C++ compiler that accepts all flags

lammps.info: LAMMPS stands for Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator. This package uses patch releases, not stable release. See https://github.com/spack/spack/pull/5342 for a detailed discussion.

netcdf-c.info: NetCDF (network Common Data Form) is a set of software libraries and machine-independent data formats that support the creation, access, and sharing of array-oriented scientific data. This is the C distribution.

netlib-scalapack.info: ScaLAPACK is a library of high-performance linear algebra routines for parallel distributed memory machines

osu-micro-benchmarks.info: The Ohio MicroBenchmark suite is a collection of independent MPI message passing performance microbenchmarks developed and written at The Ohio State University. It includes traditional benchmarks and performance measures such as latency, bandwidth and host overhead and can be used for both traditional and GPU-enhanced nodes.

parallel-netcdf.info: PnetCDF (Parallel netCDF) is a high-performance parallel I/O library for accessing files in format compatibility with Unidata's NetCDF, specifically the formats of CDF-1, 2, and 5.

git.info: Git is a free and open source distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency.

matlab.info: MATLAB (MATrix LABoratory) is a multi-paradigm numerical computing environment and fourth-generation programming language. A proprietary programming language developed by MathWorks, MATLAB allows matrix manipulations, plotting of functions and data, implementation of algorithms, creation of user interfaces, and interfacing with programs written in other languages, including C, C++, C#, Java, Fortran and Python. Note: MATLAB is licensed software. You will need to create an account on the MathWorks homepage and download MATLAB yourself. Spack will search your current directory for the download file. Alternatively, add this file to a mirror so that Spack can find it. For instructions on how to set up a mirror, see http://spack.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mirrors.html
